name: Luna Café

attributes.Ambience: {'touristy': False, 'hipster': None, 'romantic': False, 'divey': False, 'intimate': None, 'trendy': None, 'upscale': False, 'classy': False, 'casual': True}
attributes.GoodForMeal: {'dessert': False, 'latenight': False, 'lunch': True, 'dinner': False, 'brunch': True, 'breakfast': True}

categories: American (Traditional), Restaurants, Sandwiches, Caterers, Breakfast & Brunch, Coffee & Tea, Cafes, Event Planning & Services, Burgers, American (New), Vegetarian, Food
llm_reasoning: 82% - The reviews consistently reference coffee drinks (latte, espresso, cappuccino, etc.) and describe Luna Café as a cafe, indicating strong alignment with the Coffee & Tea, Cafes category, despite some mixed service/food comments.

text:
Great little neighborhood gem! It's quaint. The waitresses were attentive. The prices appropriate. And the food was sublime! I had the Cornbread Eggs Jefferson--an inventive take on the eggs Benedict (as Benedict was a traitor as so it's been renamed). First off what a great combination with the cornbread! A little sweet with savory--ham and eggs on top with a perfectly baked cornbread and doused in some sort of sweet jam! Forget the hollandaise, this was inventive Benedict heaven. 

My boyfriend had the Desayuno, a breakfast wrap filled with pulled pork, potatoes, eggs, and some sort of magic because it was so tasty, no sentence could justify its description. I suggest trying it yourself! It's spicy, it's savory, the portion was generous, and it is as my boyfriend described "the best breakfast he's had...ever."

We also ordered a stack of pumpkin chocolate pancakes which I wanted to so deeply love but the pancakes were burnt on the outside due to the fact that it was so thin...despite it being burnt it was still delicious. If it wasn't burnt it would've been phenomenal. 

Luna Cafe is definitely going to be one our go to places for brunch! Glad it's around the corner and since it's so new--has yet to be crowded. I kind of don't even want to tell people about it so this place doesn't get packed!

So. Many things were terrible. 

1. We walked in and the hostess asked if we wanted to sit inside or outside. We agreed we would prefer inside. We saw an available table, so why not? The host replied that will be a wait. We were starving, so we agreed to eat outside. 

2. The table was dirty. I'm not a snob or a neat freak, but cmon, there was cream left on the table from a previous party. 

3. There were bees everywhere. Seriously. It was so bad that I had to tell the hostess that we needed to sit inside. She basically told me all the seats were taken and rolled her eyes at me. I saw other tables trying to move and swatting bees away too. 

4. So, we order and I ask for the sweet potato bowl. During this time, me and my sister had to leave because we were a little freaked out by the bees. My fiancé called to let us know the food was there. Except my food was not. 

5. I'm waiting for my food, and realize by this point the rest of the party was finishing their dishes. The. They brought my dish. It was two pieces of cauliflower and two pieces of broccoli and some shredded carrots on a bed of quinoa. 

6. I was starving by this point, but I didn't want to eat what was served to me. My sister had to give me half of half of her sandwich so I didn't stab anyone. The waitress did not check in once and was no where to be found. 

So, if you're a trendy and hungry tourist, just go somewhere else.

I'd been craving good pancakes for ages, so I set on a long city hike on Sunday morning from Fishtown to Old City to find the perfect place- a place that wasn't too busy, wasn't too expensive, and, of course, had pancakes. Just as I was about to give up and get a breakfast sandy from Wawa, I noticed the little sidewalk sign for Luna Café. Though small and busy, I noticed a table leaving, so I decided to take the plunge.

I was riding solo and dining-in (apparently take-out is a thing here). They asked if I wanted to sit at the bar in the back. I was shocked, given the size of the small front dining area, that Luna Café had a bar, but hey? Why not? Well, to my surprise the bar what not remotely what I expected. It was small bar, more of a shelf really, lining a narrow passageway to an emergency exit/ cleaning closet. It was completely secluded and separate from the rest of the café, and I was the only one back there. I was a little confused, because when I walked in, there was a small table for two at the front. When I took my bar seat at the back, I almost felt like I was put there because I was ugly or something, hidden from the rest of the public. I'm used to dining alone, but I still enjoy the company of others. It was bizarre to be on the outside looking in, and I think the service staff nearly forgot me a handful of times.

Speaking of the service, it wasn't bad but it wasn't overly great either. I guess I was just a little salty about being sat, secluded by myself.

I ordered the pancakes ($10) with chocolate chips ($2 up charge), and a side of bacon ($3). The bacon was very greasy, and I would have liked it a bit crispier. Everyone has different bacon opinions though. The pancakes were chock-full of chips (see what I did there). They weren't super fluffy, but I could tell they were hot and homemade. They definitely satiated my cravings, though I think the $12 price tag is a little on the high end.

Luna Café has a cute little set-up for a quick morning bite, and it's located in the heart of Old City, walking distance from great sights and shops. It's about 100 steps from the 2nd and Market stop on the Market-Frankford Line, so public transport is your best bet in getting here. 

I wouldn't necessarily go out of my way to come here again. It was a pretty good meal, but the whole experience was rather forgettable.

This place is my favorite cafe in the whole city.  I love the food, the place is so cute, and the staff are all really friendly and professional. I just love everything about this place so much!  My favorite thing from Luna Cafe are the mini banana pancakes, but the first time I came here I got the regular sized ones instead.  After finishing half of one pancake I got dizzy, all of a sudden my plate was illuminated by a bright light and for one instant my breakfast appeared tall beyond measurement, beautiful beyond enduring, terrible and worshipful. I imagined myself finishing the whole plate, "I will not be full" I thought,  "I will be stuffed tighter than the foundations of the Earth!"  And as I continued to eat the remaining pancakes, I loved them.  And I despaired.  Slowly the light faded and I laughed, "I passed the test" I said softly, "I will just go to work. I don't need to finish these."   So anyway, now I order the mini banana pancakes instead.

Although the decor is cute, the service, or lack thereof, is not.

We were impressed by the menu posted on the outside of the building, so my party and I decided we would try the little place. We placed our orders: a chicken wrap, a turkey wrap and a spicy chick pea burger - substituting fries for the salad with the burger. 

It took a little longer than expected to be delivered - and when it was, it was with a "plop" on our table... one person in our party noticed that he did not have salad dressing (neither did I, but I will get to that in a minute).  He asked the waitress if he could have dressing, and she said it was already on his salad. He glanced at his salad and politely said that he didn't think there was. When he met the waitress' gaze again, she literally SNAPPED, "Yes, it is! I can see it from here!" 

During the exchange, I was wryly eyeing my salad - which by the way was lovely, but as barren as the Sahara when it came to dressing. I considered daring her to find the salad dressing on mine just to prove the point, but I demurred.  It didn't matter really since I had ordered fries as a substitute anyway. At this point I intervened in the Great Vinaigrette Debate that was playing out at the table with a request for the fries that I ordered. The waitress did apologize for that then asked if she should bring extra salad dressing to the table. Unfortunately, I was annoyed at this point and sharply replied "Yes." 

We began to eat our lunch and from the back of the cafe we could hear discussion about the fries. Apparently, it was a GREAT concern over who's "fault" it was that I did not receive fries... 

Luna Cafe... Please, if your patron doesn't see salad dressing, smile politely, apologize and get a side order. If an order is wrong, just fix it quickly and apologize. A little sugar goes a long way on customer service - Face it, it doesn't matter if YOU feel it is right or good enough - it is the customer, the one who is tipping you, who needs to be happy with their service and food. It is your JOB to make sure they are content for what they are paying for. 

Your future patrons will appreciate the "extra step" and return; we will not.

I came here with some friends for Sunday brunch, and it was ok. 

They allow you to make a reservation on OpenTable, which is super convenient. I called the day before to move up my reservation by an hour, and they were very accommodating. One of my friends arrived early, and they seated him at a table way in the back. It was a little odd, because it was the only table down a long hallway past the kitchen. I guess it was nice to have our own area, but I would have preferred to be in the main dining area.

The menu was heavily focused on breakfast food. In hindsight, I think they actually might have given us the breakfast menus because the brunch menu online has a lot of sandwiches listed that were definitely not on our menus. I usually prefer lunch food at brunch, but I do like eggs benedict, so I went with that. Their "Norwegian Eggs Jefferson" is eggs benedict with salmon, and it was pretty good. What I did not like about the dish was the "biscuits" it was served on. The biscuits tasted like really crumbly dry cornbread...gross! Also, the eggs were overcooked so that the yolks were solid. I like runny yolks with my benedict, so I was disappointed. The salmon was very good but I was surprised that it came fully cooked. I expected lox because the salmon was described as house-cured on the menu, but it still tasted very good so no complaints there. It was served with a side of fresh fruit salad that included apples, grapefruit, and oranges. I was a big fan of the fruit salad, but unfortunately the hollandaise sauce from my benedict overflowed onto the fruit salad, so it all got mixed together. It still tasted ok, though. My friends were also happy with their meals but not overly impressed. It's a BYOB, so I brought a bottle of champagne to celebrate my move to NY. We drank it straight because it was decent quality, and I didn't want to dilute it with OJ, but you can order glasses or pitchers of orange juice if you want to make mimosas.

The service was a little slow, but I think that might have been because we were in that back area. It took around 30 minutes to get our food, and I was pretty darn hungry. Our servers (we had 2) were very pleasant, though.

I owe this place at least three stars for the following two reasons:

1) I almost burnt their lovely establishment down during their Grand Opening (more on that in a minute).
2) I am hopeful this new restaurant, unlike the previous one in its place (which shall remain anonyPanini's Trattoria), will not have a staff member outside asking me to dine there every time I walk by. Usually while I'm walking my dog. Or with groceries in my hand. Or doing something similar that in no way screams "HEY LOOKING TO HAVE A GOOD MEAL WHERE SHOULD I GO?!" It's bad enough being harassed by the Big Bus Company folks and 5th and Market. And having to resist buying every adorable dog that's ever in the window at Doggie Style. If your restaurant is good, you will not need to request my presence. I'll be there. No invite necessary.

So to keep with the theme of this review, I will continue to provide my insight to you in list form (you're welcome). Here's what they're doing well.

- Décor - Love the homey, vintagey vibe with local artwork.
- Staff - Incredibly welcoming. Incredibly helpful.
- (Mostly) local sourcing, healthy, yet creative food options.
- Free champagne during grand opening. They had me at free champagne.

However, there is room for improvement.

- Paper napkins + uncovered tea lights = fire hazard. Glad I could demonstrate that to them early in their new adventure. I AM THE WORST. Luna Café, please once again accept my apologies for thinking that fanning a napkin on fire with my bill folder was a good idea.
- Food execution (see next three bullet points).
- Latke Luna - a little more salt/spice/flavor on the actual latkes. However, both dipping sauces were quite nice.
- Fritto Misto - Menu said "lightly fried," but it wasn't quite "lightly" enough. The fish they used was great and was overshadowed by too much breading.
- Caprese Focaccia Panini - Wonderful flavors, but ours was cold in the middle. Sad face.

Definitely going to come back. Probably for brunch (oh hello Brie Stuffed French Toast) and/or a juice (Green juice? Yes, please).

Unfortunately disappointing. When I looked this place up online my cousin and I had high hopes. There were lots of great reviews and their menu looked yummy. Unfortunately for us we chose to visit  a small establishment when there were a couple of larger parties dining as well. I understand a smaller kitchen can get overwhelmed, but the key to combating that is communicating with your customers - at the very least. We waited 45 minutes for eggs with no one mentioning anything about a backed up kitchen or apologizing for the delay ahead of me asking where our food was 30 minutes after putting in our order. I ordered the breakfast tacos with a latte and my cousin got an omelet with orange juice. We went in with what we thought was plenty of time of get a quick but quality breakfast (about an hour). That was not the case as we had to have them pack our food to go - which clearly wasn't even fired until after I asked where it was. Then when they said it was "coming right up" it took another 10 minutes to get it in the bag! Plus they forgot the avocado I asked to be added to my tacos. Two girls that came in after us ate and paid before our food was even plated. If someone had just mentioned something to us it would have been totally understood as we both work in the restaurant industry. Instead we received a passing nonchalant apology after the fact and no acknowledgement that they even wanted to try and save our experience for a return visit or at least a recommendation to other friends. It started off well, but we left frustrated and disappointed.

I was having an extremely pleasant bunch at here today with my friend, and we were sitting and chatting after we finished our food for no longer than 30 minutes after we had finished our food. The cafe was quiet, with about half the tables open. When my friend got up to go to the bathroom, the waiter came over to me and said "we really need to open up this table, so if you guys could leave soon"... The place was half empty and there was no line of people waiting to get in!!!! Not only that, but at another table, there was a gentleman with just a cup of coffee and his computer open, and at another table there were three girls who had all brought into the cafe with them their coffee that they bought at Starbucks!!! I have no idea why this waiter felt as though we were the people who needed to leave the cafe, but I was pretty offended by how we were treated. I get it if it was crowded and there was a wait for a table, I would have no problem with a waiter asking us to please give up the table since we were done, but there were no people waiting, and 3 empty tables in the cafe.

I think I may have liked Luna more if there had been more human interaction and some lunch options on the br"unch" menu.

First off: I suck because I walked in late. I was absolutely in Old City on time. But I had driven to the area due to our group's after-brunch plans and I'm a terrible city driver on a normal day. As it happened, half the streets were blocked off as tow-away zones for an event that we didn't know about sooo... yeah. That was fun.

Upon [late] arrival, we found that we had been placed in the reject area. Private area? Area in the back? Lone table? Isolated table? Table that was often forgotten about? Table that allowed for no people-watching? I guess it would've been okay if we had known ahead of time that we were being seated in the special area, but our group wanted to be part of the action. Plus, it took quite awhile for our server(s) to bring us our food (grumbling stomaches didn't like this!!) and our check.

As for the actual food, it was okay. Since we walked in closer to lunch-time, I really would have preferred lunch food, but the menu only had breakfast options. I didn't understand that since it was a "brunch" menu. Oddly, their online menu is different than what we saw, so perhaps we were actually given breakfast menus. Nonetheless, I chose the $13 lunaberry pancakes.

While they were okay, I don't think I'd ever want to spend $13 on pancakes topped with berries ever again. I can get them for half the price and just as good (or better) at any diner. Unfortunately, I didn't see anything else on their limited menu that sounded much better.

I'd certainly give them a second chance at some point. Maybe not for brunch just yet, but for another meal. ..And specifically request to be seated in the main dining area!

Highly disappointing. The restaurant itself was quaint and the menu looked good. So, at first sight everything looks great. 

The food was average though. And the service was below average.

My husband and I both had banana pancakes. Pretty hard to mess up, right? Well, they were sort of sour tasting and weren't fully cooked through.

The service though was the most irritating part for me. My mother-in-law ordered avocado toast with an egg. When the waitress asked how she'd like it cooked, she asked if it could be hard boiled. The waitress said, "No. We can't do that." She then asked for a poached egg and received the same answer. At that point she said, "Well, what egg can you do?" The fact that the waitress said no twice, and couldn't just say right off the bat, "I'm sorry, we have a small kitchen, so we can only do x, y, z eggs," was flat out rude. 

Meanwhile, the service that I witnessed at the tables next to us seemed pretty in line with our experience. The restaurant is tiny, so you can practically hear everything that happens.

One table ordered a side of bacon with their meal. After asking when it was coming (after they had already started eating their breakfast), the server went back to check. Nothing. They then asked a second time, and asked for a side of a sauce, and were told "It'll be right out. But, just so you know, an extra side of sauce costs a bit extra." I mean, really? I couldn't believe that came out of the waiter's mouth, after the customer asked for their bacon twice, and was practically done with their meal by the time it came. 

Another table with small children sat there for 10 minutes. A server walked by and said "Have you ordered?" The family responded, "No," and the server continued walking. The family then sat there another 5 minutes before someone came back.

Important note - Luna is cash only, but there's a TD Bank down the block, and an ATM on site. 

Came here for breakfast after seeing the great Yelp reviews and immediately after walking in, we knew we made the perfect choice. The staff is so warm and so sweet, and the place is absolutely adorable (it is tiny, but also has outdoor seating, which is an added plus). 

The menu is awesome and super varied, with really great prices. Immediately as we were seated, our server brought us coffee in the cutest mugs ever. The coffee was fresh and delicious - strong, which was what we needed considering we were at a wedding the night before. 

We started with the loaded potatoes (breakfast potatoes, melted cheese, pico de gallo, and sour cream) to share, my husband ordered the chicken and waffles, and I had the avocado toast (and added goat cheese). 

The potatoes were delicious, and my husband raved about his chicken and waffles (they looked incredible!). My avocado toast was good, my only complaint would be that there were about 4 small dots of goat cheese on them. However, the toast was so inexpensive (and delicious!), that it really didn't bother me. 

All in all, we had a delicious breakfast with great coffee and amazing service.

I highly recommend you check out this small café nestled right on Market Street. There was only one person on for wait staff when I arrived for breakfast, so I had to wait briefly before being seated, no problem (a second waiter arrived during my visit.) Many tables were full or were filling up as I sat, so the secret must be out that the food is good here! 

My order was taken pretty quickly. As I had a gluten-free request, my food naturally took a little longer to arrive, but boy, did that breakfast sandwich with turkey bacon and fontina cheese hit the spot! The appearance was thick enough (only at $7 plus extra for gluten-free bread) to suffice for a meal, but I got curious and hungry while waiting for my delicious sandwich and ordered their loaded potatoes (off my diet, but, I'm not in Philly often, so why not sample the local gourmet?)

The wait staff (friendly young woman named Brynna, I didn't catch the young man's name) were friendly, nice, and boy, were they busy! 

Back to the meal, the loaded potatoes did not disappoint! Oftentimes, restaurants tend to "overload" their potatoes or nachos with too much cheese, too much sour cream, too much grease and they come out soggy; not so with this portion. Grease level was just high enough for flavor yet not high enough to bring on instant indigestion. Portion size was also adequate: not too small, not overdone, a quality product. Brynna had shared with me that they had recently changed the recipe, so it shows that they are also reflective in continuing to refine their art.

I am a very tough critic and they earned a 4.5 out of 5 from me, which rounds up to a 5. I would plan on taking a friend here the next time I come down this way, and I recommend you do, too.

Delicious breakfast. I was craving huevo rancheros and doin his place thanks to Yelpers. Yes, it's small and you get to walk through the kitchen ( I adore that , I think it shows you have nothing to hide) to-get to the few back tables. Our server Rich was delightful and very informative. I had the winning dish although my husband thoroughly enjoyed his, he did agree. I had the huevo rancheros and it was just a flavor bomb. I did share as it was a large dish. He had the frittata with potatoes and it was good as well. I have to take off one star because the food was not hot at all when brought to the table. They were very busy so I kind of get it. Get it out hot folks and you are definitely a winner. My husband wants to go back tomorrow. I always like to try a new place.

Well after having a mediocre experience prior to the Army Navy game yesterday, we returned this morning because we needed some great grub prior to the flight home. There was Rich , happy to help once again. Today we both got the Luna bowl with two eggs ( he got bacon) with the most delicious home fried potatoes with peppers and onions topped with a fresh pico de Gallo and hot sauce. We should have shared because it was huge! But oh so good!!  A lot of West Point cadets were going in as we left and I had to stop and tell them exactly what to order! Lol!  We didn't win the game, but it doesn't matter. We are TEAM USA all the way!!

We stopped at Luna on Sunday morning around 10am. It is a small cafe and was almost full at this time, but we were lucky to be seated as party of 2 almost immediately. 

Our server arrived shortly and she was pleasant. We ordered coffee and orange juice for drinks. I ordered an omelette with tomatoes, red peppers and feta and my husband got one with avocado, turkey and feta. Both omelette got potatoes and multigrain toast on the side. We also got 3 mini pancakes. I especially asked my omelette to be well cooked but in the end, I was able to see the egg white and yellow sides pretty shiny and couldn't eat 1/3of it... Also I had a piece of avocado inside my omelet and my husband had none, but he had onions? Some mix and match going on in there... I am not a fan of pancakes, so I would say they were OK. They fill the coffee cups with a pot continuously which is a plus, but for me coffee was on the darker and strong brewed so I didn't drink much of even my first cup, but my husband enjoyed it.

While we were leaving around 11am, it got very very crowded and the door almost opened every minute. I agree with a reviewer who mentioned the door staying open and getting cold. Absolutely true!!! We were close to the door and my feet got frozen literally. If you are a cold feet, don't go there or just find a place at the back.

It is cash only place, so either go prepared or there is an ATM at the back of the cafe. I found ~50$+ gratuity on the expensive side for a brunch (saying this as a NewYorker!) which is quite rushed. we had a 14.5$ for one of the omelettes and 13$for the other which both had no extra's (3ingredients only and priced as 13$ in the menu) we didn't make a fuss for 1.5$ but didn't understand why. 

Overall I give Luna 4 (a rolled over 3.5) It is a nice small cafe where the vibe is local and nice, the food is tasty but apparently they have very high traffic in the place and this affects the service quality and experience not very positively.

TERRIBLE SERVICE! 
I wanted to enjoy a nice brunch with my boyfriend here & was completely distraught by the time we left. First we ordered 2 of the peanut butter & Nutella smoothies & asked the server how it was made because I wanted one without bananas in it. He said he didn't know how it was made because it's made in the kitchen (whatever that's supposed to mean because if you're a server these are basic things you should know) he also said there wasn't any peanut butter & when I asked the other server he said there wasn't any Nutella. So I was confused about what they had & ordered 2 berry smoothies if there wasn't any peanut butter or if they Couldn't take out the bananas & I asked if he could check with the kitchen first before anything & let us know & he made us pay for everything before we even tried any of what we ordered. We paid & tipped before any of our things came, while everyone else had the opportunity to pay once they were done their meal (there were 3 other tables in front of us that we watched this happen) We got our food & smoothies( we received one smoothie without any Nutella when I never asked for that ) didn't like the smoothies so we asked if they can just give us orange juice in exchange for one smoothie we didn't like, yet they still tried to charge us for one small $4 cup of orange juice. Our tabs total came up to $66 with the tip included & they couldn't give us a complimentary orange juice? I was about to pay for it with my card when my boyfriend tried to take my card because we were just going to leave a $5 bill for the orange juice. The server tried to snatch my card from his hand & I asked to speak to a manager & he insisted he was the manager. We said we weren't going to pay for the orange juice because that was terrible service as paying customers. He also said he was going to charge us for the orange juice anyways without our permission. I will never recommend this place if you are a person of color & I would never come back to this restaurant.

Came into Philly from NYC and was looking for a spot for a quick breakfast before venturing off to see the typical tourist attractions. Luna seemed to be closest and one of the only places open this early.

I ordered the brown sugar cardamom latte (one of the specials of the say; needed some caffeine after the super early bus ride) and the breakfast bowl -- which was quinoa with a lot of mix'ins. Now, I've had a lot of quinoa bowls, but this one was fantastically AMAZING and jam-packed with flavor. Portions were great for both the latte and the bowl. The latte came in a cute Luna Café mug as well.

***update***

I wrote the previous part of this review as I was still eating, hence why it was initially 5 stars. Dropping it to 4 solely because of the service -- the food came out quickly and was good, but no waitstaff came by at all while I was eating, yet they checked on other tables frequently. Thought that was strange. A waiter ended up handing off the check to me, I suppose after I seemed to be looking around implying I wanted someone to come over. But all that happened without me being asked whether I wanted anything else or if I even wanted the check. Service seems to be hit or miss after reading other reviews.

Two days back to back and they still didn't disappoint! They were very busy and the wait for a table for one was about 15min, which isn't bad at all. This time I payed around and had my server make the choice for me, she was a little nervous but I was confident she couldn't mess it up. The hospitality was wonderful and everyone greeted me as they walked past. No one standing still and attending everyone consistently. 

The waitresses choices were spot on, she did cheat a little by giving a sampling of biscuits and gravy (So Happy she did this!). The Breakfast Taco's are exceptionally well done, the chef that runs the kitchen knows exactly what their doing. Pico de Gallo was refreshing and not overly spicy, eggs scrambled to perfection, and the sauce poured over the taco's made them perfection! 

Now for the biscuit and gravy sampling, never have I ever had a biscuit like this before! Flaky and perfectly rounded out with a light buttery flavor, the layering makes me think it was made with Filo dough. The sausage gravy richly flavored and had no grit from the sausage. Perfectly seasoned and not overly peppered or salted, most make their gravy greasy and under seasoned, this will not disappoint! 

Do Not Miss this spot to have breakfast or brunch! This will make your trip or day and will be back for more.

We walked into the cafe in the direction of the counter and as we stood there, there were two people behind the counter - young man and older woman. Neither really spoke to us for few minutes as we awkwardly stood in pretty tight enclosed space. At some point the woman standing there writing in her notepad looked up and asked if we were being helped which we obviously weren't as she and the other guy that could've spoken to us. She asked for our vaccine cards before anything (which isn't a problem until a bit later) and then told us there were counter seats in the back or we can just wait for one of the tables to be cleaned and we can sit there. We opted to wait and we're seated shortly after. While we waited for someone to take our order, about two more crowds walked in and were politely greeted immediately and told them someone would be with them in one minute. Right after, another group walked in and after being greeted, they were advised to have a seat and would be asked to show their cards when someone came to the table.

My partner and I immediately noticed a large difference in customer care between us and the groups following us; I'm not one to say this often but it definitely felt like it was because we're are people of color.
We decided not to eat there and didn't even bother to try their food based on their service. I'm a big fan of small cafe's but this was disrespectful for my own taste - Philly has much better places!
